awd_titl_txt: Defining the Role of RACK1 in Ephrin Reverse Signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing nerve cells must often migrate through the brain to form the circuits that control behavior, but how this process is controlled is not understood. One group of molecules that are important for nerve cell migration (called Ephrins) exist as multiple types in mammals, making their detailed functions difficult to study. Taking advantage of the fact that insects (including the tobacco hornworm Manduca used here) produce a single type of Ephrin protein, a molecule (RACK1) that Ephrin interacts with in a major way during nerve cell development has been identified. This project will determine how RACK1 works together with Ephrin to regulate nerve cell migration and circuit development. The new discoveries made during this project will provide valuable information about how Ephrins function during nervous system development in more complex animals, including the human brain. The project will also provide unique opportunities for undergraduate students to learn advanced methods for investigating how specific proteins regulate nerve cell growth. Students will conduct experiments in Manduca to test the role of Ephrin and RACK1 in this process, and to identify other proteins that are required for Ephrin function. The data and resources produced by this project will be presented at major scientific conferences, published in scientific journals, and be posted on web sites that are freely available to other scientists and to the public. In addition, discoveries from this project will be presented to more general audiences at the Oregon Health and Science University Brain Fair, an interactive educational opportunity that is held annually at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry.

This project will investigate how type-A Ephrins (which are attached to cells by GPI lipid anchors) can regulate the activity of intracellular tyrosine kinases in the Src family, and how this signaling pathway controls the migratory behavior of developing neurons. Preliminary studies indicate that the adapter protein RACK1 (Receptor of Activated Protein Kinase C) functions as a molecular rheostat that restricts Src signaling until MsEphrin signaling is initiated. Studies will be carried out using a well-characterized assay of neuronal migration in cultured Manduca embryos. Targeted manipulations of gene expression will test whether RACK1 is essential for the activation of a specific Src kinase (Src42) by type-A Ephrins. Biochemical assays of Src activity and Src-RACK1 interactions will test whether RACK1 functions as both a regulator and substrate for Src42 in this process. Time-lapse imaging and quantitative assays of neuronal migration will be used to investigate how this signaling pathway affects specific aspects of neuronal behavior in the developing nervous system. Similar methods will test whether a toll family protein (Toll-7) functions as a novel co-receptor for type-A Ephrins in this pathway. These experiments will also permit the downstream effectors of type-A Ephrins to be identified in related projects that will be conducted by selected undergraduate participants.

Outcomes for Intellectual Merit of project:   

During the formation of the nervous system, most nerve cells (neurons) must actively migrate considerable distances from their initial birth zones to reach their final locations, which allows them to form functional circuits that control thought, behavior, and memory.  However, the actual mechanisms that control neuronal migration remain poorly understood, in part because of the complexity of the mammalian brain. To investigate this question, we used a simpler model system (the hawkmoth Manduca), which permits experimental tests of neuronal migration to be performed within the developing nervous system. In particular, we discovered a novel role for a set of guidance molecules (found in all animals) that are called Ephrins and Eph Receptors. In our preliminary studies, we had shown that an unusual type of signaling called ?Ephrin reverse signaling? prevents migrating neurons from traveling abnormally into inappropriate regions of the developing nervous system. During reverse signaling, Eph receptors activate Ephrin-dependent responses in neurons, a process that has now been detected more complex organisms (including human tissues). By exploiting the unique advantages of Manduca as an experimental preparation, we discovered that Ephrin reverse signaling functions by activating a ?molecular rheostat? in neurons, consisting of a well-known signaling protein (Src42) and a more mysterious linker protein (RACK1). We also identified that activation of this response involves a novel co-receptor (Toll 7), which transmits the response of activated Ephrins across the cell membrane to engage the RACK1/Src42 rheostat via another signaling protein, phospholipase C (PLC); illustrated in Figure 1. Intriguingly, work by several undergraduates in my laboratory identified several additional proteins that may further regulate Ephrin reverse signaling in migrating neurons, including RhoA (which regulates structural components of developing neurons) and a ?G protein? (Goa) that relays signals from other guidance cue and may also tune the rheostat. 

In summary, the scope of the proposed work for this project is now complete. The significance of these discoveries is that they define how Ephrin reverse signaling functions to control the migratory behavior of developing neurons. They also provide the framework for future investigations that will investigate how this signaling mechanism controls different aspects of nervous system development in more complex animals (including humans), and how Ephrin-dependent responses can be integrated with other guidance cues to integrate new neurons into functional circuits.

Outcomes for Broader Impacts of project:

  This project also provided eight undergraduate students with advanced laboratory experience, including mentoring in scientific principles, experimental applications, and scientific communication.  As part of my Broader Impacts activities, resources associated with this project were also used to support laboratory experiences for ~40 undergraduates at Pacific University, and to provide educational presentations to the general public (summarized below). Over the course of this project, 33% of my trainees were from underrepresented minorities or economically challenged backgrounds, and 80% were women. One of my undergraduates (Ms. Colleen Kawamoto) was selected for participation in an REU project in year 1 of the project, which she continued during the subsequent school year.  A second undergraduate (Ms. Grace Walker-Stevenson) participated in an REU project in year 2 of the project, and she also continued to participate in the project during the following school years. A third undergraduate (Ms. Chandelle Bates) was participated in an REU project in year 3. In addition, another of my undergraduate trainees (Ms. Margaret Rose) continued the project initiated by a Colleen Kawamoto to explore a novel role for the heterotrimeric G protein Goa during MsEphrin signaling. These projects provided unique opportunities for these budding young scientists to advance their training in bench work and experimental design, and I am pleased that most of them intend to pursue their interests in biomedical science in their future careers.

As noted above, I also incorporated resources generated from this project to support several Outreach efforts, including annual presentations at the Brain Fair at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry, Portland OR; support for undergraduate research projects at Pacific University (with Dr. David Scholnik); small group instructional Tours of the Moth World for grade school students and parents from a variety of backgrounds and expertise; and the generation of ?life cycles? sets of Manduca sexta for teachers to create terrarium-based presentations on animal development, metamorphosis, and insect biology. These outreach activities provide unique opportunities to introduce students at all levels to the biology of Lepidoptera, leading to discussions about different life strategies for growth, maturation, and reproduction in different organisms. I have also continued to provide local classrooms with sets of Manduca (including all life stages) for displays that the teachers can use in their programs.  In combination, these activities have supported the Broader Impacts of this project, providing important opportunities to expand scientific awareness and understanding to many members of the community.
